It also gives JavaScript a good workout to keep it light and nimble. We're talking…

Input

modern JS


            const random = (array) => {
              const i = Math.floor(Math.random() * array.length);
              return array[i];
            };

            const counterparts = ['potato', 'JavaScript'];

            console.log(`At the end of the day it's all just ${random(counterparts)}`);

Output

cross-browser-compatible JS


            "use strict";

            var random = function random(array) {
              var i = Math.floor(Math.random() * array.length);
              return array[i];
            };

            var counterparts = ['potato', 'JavaScript'];
            console.log("At the end of the day it's all just ".concat(random(counterparts)));

bundle splitting

lazy loading

split configs per environment
